description:
Delphinus delphis, commonly known as the common dolphin, is a species of dolphin found in temperate and tropical waters around the world. It is a member of the family Delphinidae, which includes many other dolphin species.

The common dolphin is a medium-sized dolphin, typically ranging from 1.7 to 2.4 meters in length and weighing between 70 to 235 kilograms. It has a distinctive hourglass-shaped pattern on its flanks, with a dark gray back, light gray sides, and a white belly. The species is known for its agile and acrobatic behavior, often seen leaping out of the water and performing other impressive maneuvers.

Common dolphins are highly social animals, living in large pods that can number in the hundreds or even thousands. They are known to be cooperative hunters, working together to herd and corral their prey, which includes a variety of small fish, squid, and crustaceans. The species is considered to be of Least Concern on the IUCN Red List, although they face threats from bycatch in commercial fisheries and environmental pollution.
